message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Increasing sample size would allow for a greater number of patients to be studied, increasing the likelihood of detecting rare adverse effects. Decreasing post-market surveillance time would not be relevant to the study. Non-randomization and increasing selection bias would both decrease the accuracy of the study and make it more difficult to detect any adverse effects, rather than increase the chances of detecting them.

Increasing sample size would increase the chances of detecting a significant adverse effect as it would increase the statistical power of the study. Post-market surveillance time refers to monitoring a drug after it has been approved for sale, which would not be relevant to this randomized and controlled study. Non-randomization and increasing selection bias would both decrease the validity of the study and its ability to accurately detect adverse effects.

Increasing the sample size would increase the statistical power and therefore increase the chances of detecting a significant adverse effect if it exists. Decreasing post-market surveillance time would decrease the amount of time available to detect adverse effects, while non-randomization and increasing selection bias can both lead to bias in the study and potentially mask adverse effects.

Decreasing post-market surveillance time would not affect the results of the randomized trial. Non-randomization and increasing selection bias would both decrease the validity of the study but would not necessarily increase the chances of detecting adverse effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Increasing sample size is the most likely factor to increase the chances of detecting a significant adverse effect. This is because a larger sample size means a greater number of participants are being studied, leading to a higher chance of identifying rare adverse effects. Decreasing post-market surveillance time, non-randomization, and increasing selection bias are not factors that would increase the chances of detecting adverse effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Increasing sample size is the most likely to increase the chances of detecting a significant adverse effect. This is because a larger sample size increases the statistical power of the study and reduces the chance of a type II error, which is failing to detect an actual difference or effect. Decreasing post-market surveillance time would not be relevant for detecting adverse effects during a research study. Non-randomization and increasing selection bias may increase the risk of confounding variables and reduce the internal validity of the study, but they are not specific to detecting adverse effects.

We refer to the principles of medical research for help. Increasing sample size would increase the power of the study and increase the chances of detecting a significant adverse effect, if one exists. Decreasing post-market surveillance time would not affect the study itself, but rather the monitoring of the medication after it is approved for use. Non-randomization and increasing selection bias would compromise the validity and reliability of the study results.

Decreasing post-market surveillance time will not affect the results of a controlled study. Non-randomization and increasing selection bias can introduce bias into the study, but they do not specifically affect the detection of adverse effects.
